Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks spilling over the sides. My partner’s voice echoes in my mind, “Can you help with the folding tonight? I’ve got a late meeting.” I nod, but my thoughts are already drifting to the construction site. This morning, the foreman posted a notice about an optional training session next week—extra safety protocols, new equipment. He said it’s not mandatory, but everyone knows the guys who show up are the ones who get noticed for promotions. I want to be that guy. But the session is in the evening, the only time I have to catch up at home. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. At home, I’m expected to pull my weight, not just drop my boots and disappear. At work, I’m expected to be committed, to show I’m serious about the job. I look at the laundry, then at the training notice in my hand, and my chest tightens. I can’t be in two places at once, but both places need me.
